Svayambhu

Digital Critical Edition and Translation of an Old Javanese Juridical Text

Edited by Arlo Griffiths & Timothy Lubin

  • Witnesses
  • Metadata

List of Witnesses

  • L: Leiden, Universiteitsbibliotheek, the Netherlands, Or. 4530: Balinese script on paper, van der Tuuk collection
  • K: Kirtya, Singaraja, Bali, Indonesia, 774 (kropak 3) II A/3/774: Balinese script on lontar
  • M: Kirtya, Singaraja, Bali, Indonesia, 280 (kropak 3): Balinese script on lontar; transcripts HKS 3046; also LOr?
  • SvaMSS: The Sanskrit text as implied by the Svayambhu manuscripts
  • EdO: Olivelle, Patrick. 2005. Manu’s Code of Law: A Critical Edition and Translation of the Mānava-Dharmásāstra. New York: Oxford University Press.

Metadata of the Edition

  • Title: Svayambhu. Digital Critical Edition and Translation of an Old Javanese Juridical Text

L1K1v//0// avighnam astu //0//

1.

Account of Dharma

1.

anuṣṭubh
vyavahārān didr̥kṣus tu brāhmaṇaiḥ saha pārthivaḥ mantrajñair mantribhiś caiva vinītaḥ praviśet sabhām ||

  • MDhŚ08.001
1.1

kunaṅ hulaha saṅ prabhu, uniṅānira taṅ vyavahāranikaṅ rāt, harovaṅa ta sira brāhmaṇa vihikan maṅaji, lavan mantri vruh(1) mavivekā(2), sulakṣaṇaha ta sira tumamaha riṅ sabhā.

2.

anuṣṭubh
tatrāsīnaḥ sthito vāpi pāṇim udyamya dakṣiṇam | vinītaveṣābharaṇaḥ paśyet kāryāṇi kāryiṇām ||

  • MDhŚ08.002
2.1

haliṅgihāpagəha(3) ta sira riṅ sabhā, taṅanira tṅən hatah ulahaknira(4), hayvātuduh-tuduh(5) kiva, bhūṣaṇa-pahyasniṅ vvaṅ suśīlātah lviranira, iṅət-iṅətənirātah yogyāyogyani kāryanikaṅ mavyavahāra kalih.

3.

anuṣṭubh
pratyahaṁ deśadr̥ṣṭaiś ca śāstradr̥ṣṭaiś ca hetubhiḥ | aṣṭādaśasu mārgeṣu nibaddhāni pr̥thak pr̥thak ||

  • MDhŚ08.003
3.1

*sari masiha sirān ṅiṅət-iṅəta makasādhanaṅ(6) vara-varah saṅ hyaṅ āgama mānavādi(7), mvaṅ sakinapagəhaknikaṅ sapañjiṅ deśanya, deśa ṅaranya,(8) sadaṅayan, sajamus vuṅkal, savuravan, sakanuruhan, an hana *kaparǝkanya deniṅ āgama, ya hika deśadr̥ṣṭa ṅaranya, aṅkǝn(9) deśa sasiki svadeśanikaṅ vyavahāra, aṣṭādaśasu mārgeṣu(10), irikā sthānaniṅ vyavahāra vvalu(11) vlas kvehnya, salviraniṅ vicāraniṅ(12) vyavahāra, hana tinmunya ṅkāna salah siki, paḍa madudva-dudvan(13) viṣayanya.

4.

anuṣṭubh
hiṁsāṁ yaḥ kurute kaś cid deyaṁ vā na prayacchati | sthāne te dve vivādasya bhinno ’ṣṭādaśadhā punaḥ ||

  • This stanza is absent from Boisselier 1963(Srinivasan 1972(Pachow 1958(Bhattacharya 1985(n.d.(Rajaguru 1963(Krishna Rao 1938–1939(Krishna Rao 1938–1939(Bautze-Picron 2014(Lakshmana Rao 1927–1928(BOISSELIER 1995(<i>Bulletin de l’École française d’Extrême-Orient, tome XXXVI, 1936 1937(Jordaan and Colless 2009(Mallinson 2019(“Full Text” n.d.(Bambang Sulistyo 2018(Zoetmulder 2006(Zoetmulder 1993(Subbarayalu 2012(“Contient Les Termes Utilisés Dans Les Textes Sanskrits Relatifs Au Droit et à,” n.d.(Olivelle, Brick, and McClish 2015(Olivelle 2013(Churmatin Nasoichah 2017(Liefrinck 1927(Lekkerkerker 1918’s constituted text, though it is referenced in his app. crit. for one manuscript. The stanza occurs in ed. Boisselier 1963(Srinivasan 1972(Pachow 1958(Bhattacharya 1985(n.d.(Rajaguru 1963(Krishna Rao 1938–1939(Krishna Rao 1938–1939(Bautze-Picron 2014(Lakshmana Rao 1927–1928(BOISSELIER 1995(<i>Bulletin de l’École française d’Extrême-Orient, tome XXXVI, 1936 1937(Jordaan and Colless 2009(Mallinson 2019(“Full Text” n.d.(Bambang Sulistyo 2018(Zoetmulder 2006(Zoetmulder 1993(Subbarayalu 2012(“Contient Les Termes Utilisés Dans Les Textes Sanskrits Relatifs Au Droit et à,” n.d.(Olivelle, Brick, and McClish 2015(Olivelle 2013(Churmatin Nasoichah 2017(Liefrinck 1927(Lekkerkerker 1918 8.4 with reading bhinno, where the Svayambhu implies bhinne.
4.1

hiṁsāṁ yaḥ(14) kurute kaś cit, hana vvaṅ mamātyani nirdoṣa, maṅlarani nirdoṣa,(15) kunaṅ deyam vā(16) na prayacchati(17), tan paveh irikaṅ yogya vehakna(18), aveh irikaṅ tan yogya vehaknanya kunaṅ, sthāne(19) te dve vivādasya, ya ikā(20) sthānaniṅ vyavahāra, rvaṅ siki mūlanya(21), bhinne(22) ’ṣṭādaśadhā(23) punaḥ, matmahan ta ya vvalu vlas vkasan.

5.

anuṣṭubh
teṣām ādyam r̥ṇādānaṁ nikṣepo ’svāmivikrayaḥ | saṁbhūya ca samutthānaṁ dattasyānapakarma ca ||

  • MDhŚ08.004
anuṣṭubh
vetanasyaiva cādānaṁ saṁvidaś ca vyatikramaḥ | krayavikrayānuśayo vivādaḥ svāmipālayoḥ ||

  • MDhŚ08.005
anuṣṭubh
sīmāvivādadharmaś ca pāruṣye daṇḍavācike | steyaṁ ca sāhasaṁ caiva strīsaṁgrahaṇam eva ca ||

  • MDhŚ08.006
anuṣṭubh
strīpuṁdharmo vibhāgaś ca dyūtam āhvāna(24) eva ca | padāny aṣṭādaśaitāni vyavahārasthitāv iha ||

  • MDhŚ08.007
5.1

lvirnya: teṣām ādyam r̥ṇādānam(25), tan kasahuraniṅ hutaṅ(26), hādiniṅ vyavahāra. nikṣepa, tan kavehaniṅ patuvava. asvāmivikraya(27), hadval tan dr̥vya. sambhūya ca samutthānam(28), tan kaduman ulihiṅ kinabehan. dattasyānapakarma(29) ca, *karuddhāniṅ(30) huvus vinehakən.

5.2

vetanasyaiva cādānam(31), tan kavehaniṅ upahan. samvidaś ca vyatikramaḥ, advā riṁ samaya. krayavikrayānuśayo(32), alarāmbəknyān pamlinya kunaṅ. vivādaḥ svāmipālayoḥ(33), vivādaniṅ(34) *pinaṅvanakən mvaṅ maṅvan.

5.3

sīmāvivādadharmaś(35) ca, kahucapaniṅ vatəs. pāruṣye daṇḍavācike, ḍaṇḍaniṅ sāhasa(36), vākpāruṣya. steyam(37), pavr̥ttiniṅ maliṅ. sāhasam, ulah sāhasa. strīsaṁgrahaṇam eva ca(38), ulah tan yogya riṅ lakī strī.

5.4

...(39) vibhāgaś(40) ca, kadumaniṅ dr̥vya. dyūtam(41), totohan tan(42) prāṇi. āhvānam(43), totohan prāṇi. padāny aṣṭādaśaitāni(44), nahan ta vvalu(45) vlas lvirnya. vyavahārasthitānīha(46), byakta pinakasthānaniṅ(47) vyavahāra.

6.

anuṣṭubh
eṣu sthāneṣu bhūyiṣṭhaṁ vivādaṁ caratāṁ nr̥ṇām | dharmaṁ śāśvatam āśritya kuryāt kāryavinirṇayam ||

  • MDhŚ08.008
6.1

eṣu sthāneṣu bhūyiṣṭham(48), ikaṅ vyavahārasthāna vvalu(49) vlas, kapva hana katmunya(50) ṅkana, kapagəhakna saṅ prabhu, yuktinikaṅ vyavahāranya, apan gavayaknanira pagəh i kāryanikaṅ(51) yogya pagəhaknanira.

7.

anuṣṭubh
yadā svayaṁ na kuryāt tu nr̥patiḥ kāryadarśanam | tadā niyuñjyād vidvāṁsaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ kāryadarśane ||

  • MDhŚ08.009
7.1

kunaṅ saṅ prabhu hayva sira gumavayakən ikaṅ kāryāmivakṣa guṇadoṣa, hakona ta sira ri(52) saṅ brāhmaṇa(53) vihikan maṅaji(54), kumavruhana yogyanikaṅ vvaṅ mavyavahāra kalih.

8.

anuṣṭubh
aṣṭādaśapadābhijñaṁ prāḍvivāketi saṁjñitam | ānvīkṣikyāṁ ca kuśalaṁ śrutismr̥tiparāyaṇam ||

  • This stanza is absent from the constituted text in Boisselier 1963(Srinivasan 1972(Pachow 1958(Bhattacharya 1985(n.d.(Rajaguru 1963(Krishna Rao 1938–1939(Krishna Rao 1938–1939(Bautze-Picron 2014(Lakshmana Rao 1927–1928(BOISSELIER 1995(<i>Bulletin de l’École française d’Extrême-Orient, tome XXXVI, 1936 1937(Jordaan and Colless 2009(Mallinson 2019(“Full Text” n.d.(Bambang Sulistyo 2018(Zoetmulder 2006(Zoetmulder 1993(Subbarayalu 2012(“Contient Les Termes Utilisés Dans Les Textes Sanskrits Relatifs Au Droit et à,” n.d.(Olivelle, Brick, and McClish 2015(Olivelle 2013(Churmatin Nasoichah 2017(Liefrinck 1927(Lekkerkerker 1918, though it is referenced in his app. crit. for ms. Ox2 after 8.9. Mandlik (p. 877) and Jha include the stanza at the beginning of Medhātithi’s comment on 8.9; in his notes, Jha (v. 9, p. 490) cites citations of this verse in medieval scholastic works. In contrast with the cases in Div. XX and YY, van Naerssen (van Naerssen 1956) did not notice that the Old Javanese text here implies the presence of this stanza because the Sanskrit original is not quoted.
8.1

saṅ brāhmaṇa saṅ vruh riṅ aṣṭādaśavyavahāra,(55) sira ta saṅ sinaṅguh prāgvivāka(56), saṅ vruh riṅ aji tarka(57) vruha riṅ śruti veda.

9.

anuṣṭubh
vivāde pr̥cchati praśnaṁ pratipraśnaṁ tathaiva ca | priyapūrvaṁ prāg vadati prāḍvivākas tataḥ smr̥taḥ ||

  • This stanza is present neither in the constituted text of Boisselier 1963(Srinivasan 1972(Pachow 1958(Bhattacharya 1985(n.d.(Rajaguru 1963(Krishna Rao 1938–1939(Krishna Rao 1938–1939(Bautze-Picron 2014(Lakshmana Rao 1927–1928(BOISSELIER 1995(<i>Bulletin de l’École française d’Extrême-Orient, tome XXXVI, 1936 1937(Jordaan and Colless 2009(Mallinson 2019(“Full Text” n.d.(Bambang Sulistyo 2018(Zoetmulder 2006(Zoetmulder 1993(Subbarayalu 2012(“Contient Les Termes Utilisés Dans Les Textes Sanskrits Relatifs Au Droit et à,” n.d.(Olivelle, Brick, and McClish 2015(Olivelle 2013(Churmatin Nasoichah 2017(Liefrinck 1927(Lekkerkerker 1918, nor in its app. crit., but is known to have occurred in the Br̥haspatismr̥ti, a text often cited by medieval Indian dharmaśāstra authors. The Old Javanese paraphrase suggests that its author knew the Sanskrit stanza with a reading vicāre for vivāde.

    Brh_1,1.69
9.1

kunaṅ ikaṅ tantraniṅ vicāra, gavayakna rumuhun, sādhana saṅ prāgvivāka matakvan(58) irikaṅ(59) mavyavahāra kalih, vivekanira ta sahurnya vkasan, mataṅhyan prāgvivāka pva ṅaranira.

10.

anuṣṭubh
so ’sya kāryāṇi saṁpaśyet sabhyair eva tribhir vr̥taḥ | sabhām eva praviśyāgryām āsīnaḥ sthita eva vā ||

  • MDhŚ08.010
10.1

haṅiṅət-iṅəta ta(60) saṅ prāgvivāka, hi kāryanikaṅ(61) mavyavahāra kalih, harovaṅa ta sira vvaṅ yogya riṅ sabhā(62) tigaṅ viji, tumamaha(63) ta sirāluṅguhāpagəha(64) riṅ sabhā.

11.

anuṣṭubh
yasmin deśe niṣīdanti viprā vedavidas trayaḥ | rājñaś ca prakr̥to vidvān brahmaṇas tāṁ sabhāṁ viduḥ ||

  • MDhŚ08.011
11.1

saṅ brāhmaṇa tigaṅ siki, paḍa vruh maṅaji, hana brāhmaṇa sasiki prajñān vidagdha, vinidhi muṅgva riṅ deśa saṅ prabhu, ikaṅ deśa papupulanira, yeka deśa sabhā ṅaranya de saṅ paṇḍita(65).

12.

upajāti
na sā sabhā yatra na santi vr̥ddhā vr̥ddhā na te ye na vadanti dharmam | nāsau dharmo yatra na satyam asti na tat satyaṁ yac chalenānuviddham ||

  • NarSm mā. 3.17/NMS vya. 80

  • dharmo viddhas tv adharmeṇa sabhāṁ yatropatiṣṭhate | śalyaṁ cāsya na kr̥ntanti viddhās tatra sabhāsadaḥ ||

    MDhŚ08.012
12.1

ikaṅ sabhā(66), yan tan ana saṅ vr̥ddhah tan sabhā ṅaranya, saṅ vr̥ddhah yan tan vruh iṅ(67) dharma, tan vr̥ddhaḥ ṅaranira, saṅ vruh iṅ(68) dharma yan tan agəgvana(69) kajātyan, tan dharma ṅaranikā, kunaṅ yan tan ginavayakən(70) ikaṅ dharma riṅ sabhā, sukət paṅəməh ṅaranikā sahaneṅ(71) sabhā, mapan(72) ikaṅ deśa kinahananiṅ dharma, tan kavoraniṅ(73) adharmi, yeka sabhā ṅaranya.

13.

anuṣṭubh
sabhā vā na praveṣṭavyā vaktavyaṁ vā samañjasam | abruvan vibruvan vāpi naro bhavati kilbiṣī ||

  • MDhŚ08.013
13.1

kunaṅ hikaṅ vvaṅ haṅujarakən prāya yukti, salah denya vkasan, makveh ujarnya, vvaṅ katon doṣanya(74), ika ta kabeh tan yogya tumamaha riṅ sabhā.

14.

anuṣṭubh
yatra dharmo hy adharmeṇa satyaṁ yatrānr̥tena ca | hanyate prekṣamāṇānāṁ hatās tatra sabhāsadaḥ ||

  • MDhŚ08.014
14.1

mataṅyan maṅkana, dharmanika saṅ uniṅa riṅ dharma, hilaṅ ikā deniṅ adharma riṅ sabhā, kasatyanira(75) maṅkanātah hilaṅnikā deniṅ adva riṅ sabhā, yapvan alah juga dharma deniṅ adharma, halah juga satya deniṅ adva, paḍa hana pva ya riṅ sabhā, patimbunaniṅ(76) kunapa ṅaraniṅ sabhā yan maṅkana.

15.

anuṣṭubh
dharma eva hato hanti dharmo rakṣati rakṣitaḥ | tasmād dharmo na hantavyo mā no dharmo hato ’vadhīt ||

  • MDhŚ08.015
15.1

kunaṅ yan iṅilaṅakən saṅ hyaṅ dharma, malǝs juga sira maṅilaṅakən, yan rinakṣa saṅ hyaṅ dharma malǝs juga sira maṅrakṣa(77), mataṅyan(78) maṅkana, hayvāṅilaṅakən dharma, liṅniṅ vvaṅ, tan paṅilaṅakən pva kita(79) dharma, tan paṅilaṅakən sira hiri ya, maṅkana(80) liṅ atǝhər pramāṇastava(81).

16.

  • unknown
16.1

hapan(82) tan ana lǝviha sakeṅ dharma, sira pinakapramāṇan riṅ(83) loka, sira ta pinakasvarga saṅ magavesamagave hayu, sira pinakakalǝpasan saṅ paṇḍita, tan maṅkana hikaṅ vvaṅ adharma, tan ana gumantyanagamantyanya maṅkanāta saṅka pisana tuvi.(84)

17.

  • unknown
17.1

mapan ikaṅ loka kabeh, dharma humagəhakən ika, kinapagəhakən pva sira de saṅ yatna, malǝsira magəhakən, apan tan pāpa hikaṅ loka(87) maṅkana, ikaṅ tan aṅilaṅakən dharma.

18.

anuṣṭubh
vr̥ṣo hi bhagavān dharmas tasya yaḥ kurute tv alam | vr̥ṣalaṁ taṁ vidur devās tasmād dharmaṁ na lopayet ||

  • MDhŚ08.016
18.1

mataṅnyan(88) maṅkana, lǝmbu rūpa bhaṭāra(89) dharma, hana ta vvaṅ(90) tan agave dharma, yeka pāpa liṅniṅ deva, maṅkana pva ya, hayva kita maṅilaṅakən dharma.

19.

anuṣṭubh
eka eva suhr̥d dharmo nidhāne ’py anuyāti yaḥ | śarīreṇa samaṁ nāśaṁ sarvam anyad dhi gacchati ||

  • MDhŚ08.017
19.1

saṅ(91) tumut ri kālaniṅ pati sira ta bhaṭāra dharma, mitra tan pakarva pva, parǝṅ ilaṅ mvaṅ śarīra, mvaṅ dharma, kunaṅ hikaṅ dr̥vya len sakerika, salah paran ika.

20.

anuṣṭubh
pādo ’dharmasya kartāraṁ pādaḥ sākṣiṇam r̥cchati | pādaḥ sabhāsadaḥ sarvān pādo rājānam r̥cchati ||

  • MDhŚ08.018
20.1

saṅ hyaṅ dharma saparǝpatan(92) tinǝmuniṅ mavyavahāra yan satya, maṅkana hikaṅ sākṣi yan satya, hanmu saparǝpatanira(93) saṅ hyaṅ(94) dharma, maṅkana saṅ mavivakṣa kabeh, yan satya hanǝmu saparǝpatanira(95) saṅ hyaṅ dharmātah, saṅ prabhu hanǝmu saparǝpatanirātah(96), hagəṅ juga phalaniṅ kasatyan(97) ginavayakən.

21.

anuṣṭubh
rājā bhavaty anenās tu mucyante ca sabhāsadaḥ | eno gacchati kartāraṁ nindārho yatra nindyate ||

  • MDhŚ08.019
21.1

saṅ prabhu tan kahanan sira riṅ(98) pāpa, saṅ mavivakṣa kabeh luput sira riṅ pāpa, ikaṅ mavyavahāra salah pakṣanya juga təmpuhanya, nininda siṅ(99) saṅkananya, (100) deśa kahananya.

22.

anuṣṭubh
jātimātropajīvī vā kāmaṁ syād brāhmaṇabruvaḥ | dharmapravaktā nr̥pater na tu śūdraḥ kathaṁ cana ||

  • MDhŚ08.020
anuṣṭubh
yasya śūdras tu kurute rājño dharmavivecanam | tasya sīdati tad rāṣṭraṁ paṅke gaur iva paśyataḥ ||

  • MDhŚ08.021
22.1

maṅkana saṅ prabhu, yan śūdra prāgvivākanira, kaḍatvanira durbala(101) kṣaya, kadi lǝmbu kaptək riṅ(102) latək ajro.

  • Bhīṣmaparva 124.19: kadi lǝmbu kapǝtǝk iṅ latǝk

23.

anuṣṭubh
yad rāṣṭraṁ śūdrabhūyiṣṭhaṁ nāstikākrāntam advijam | vinaśyaty āśu tat kr̥tsnaṁ durbhikṣavyādhipīḍitam ||

  • MDhŚ08.022
23.1

ikaṅ rājya, yan kakehaniṅ(103) śūdra, hakveh vvaṅ(104) manayākən deva hiriya, tan pabrāhmaṇa, ikaṅ rājya maṅkana, śīghra hilaṅ deniṅ lapā vyādhi bhaya kaḍatvanira.

24.

  • vyavahārān svayaṁ paśyet sabhyaiḥ parivr̥to ’nvaham || YDh 1.360 = BṛhSm 1.1.106]

    unknown
24.1

maṅkana pva ya, maṅutusa ta sirāmivakṣaha, vvaṅ vruh iṅ āgama, śīghra maṅucapa yan tinakvanan, saṅ makveh kavruhnira(105) śruti veda, paḍaməlakna vataṅan pāt, ikaṅ vet an pamivakṣana*, sakveh saṅ humuṅguh(106) irika, sira ta(107) paḍa umiṅət-iṅəta sarasaniṅ vyavahāra.

25.

anuṣṭubh
dharmāsanam adhiṣṭhāya saṁvītāṅgaḥ samāhitaḥ | praṇamya lokapālebhyaḥ kāryadarśanam ārabhet ||

  • MDhŚ08.023
25.1

maṅkanānakna(108) sajiniṅ vataṅan, apuy riṅ payajñan(109), kumbha mesya bañu, halalaṅ, sarvavīja,(110) maṇik curiga muṅgva riṅ səṇḍi. tumama pva saṅ prāgvivāka riṅ sabhā, mavḍihana, asalimputa(111), maṅañjaliha riṅ caturlokapāla, lumkasa ta sira maṅiṅət-iṅəta kāryanikaṅ mavyavahāra kalih.

26.

anuṣṭubh
arthānarthāv ubhau buddhvā dharmādharmau ca kevalau | varṇakrameṇa sarvāṇi paśyet kāryāṇi kāryiṇām ||

  • MDhŚ08.025
26.1

kavruhananira kaṅ ujar adon lavan tan padon, mvaṅ ikaṅ(112) tuhu lavan adva, nahan ta kāryanikaṅ vyavahāra kalih, iniṅət-iṅətǝnira, tumutana kramaniṅ varṇanikaṅ vyavahāra.

27.

anuṣṭubh
bāhyair vibhāvayel liṅgair bhāvam antargataṁ nr̥ṇām | svaravarṇeṅgitākāraiś cakṣuṣā ceṣṭitena ca ||

  • MDhŚ08.025
27.1

132.

anuṣṭubh

yaḥ svāminānanujñātam ādhiṁ bhūṅkte ’vicakṣaṇaḥ | tenārdhavr̥ddhir moktavyā tasya bhogasya niṣkr̥tiḥ ||

  • Our author seems to have known the first Sanskrit stanza with the reading ādhisīmā. It is unclear whether he knew the second at all — whether the phrases after tan ilaṅa ya still concern the first stanza, whether they are a loose rendering of stanza 150 as we know it, or whether they correspond to a radically different version of that stanza. The use of a lowest-level instead of final punctuation after tan ilaṅa ya in all three manuscripts suggests that the scribes regarded what follows as part of the preceding paraphrase.

    MDhŚ08.149-08.150
132.1

tan· pva Ltan vruḥ pa Ktakvanǝn conj.
takvan LK
We cannot make sense of the text as it is transmitted, with takvan, as we require a passive verb form. There are rather numerous occurrences of takvanana in our text and in others, while takvanǝn is scarcely attested anywhere, but we favor this emendation as it seems easier to understand how the error takvan ikaṅ might have arisen from takvanǝn ikaṅ than from takvanana ikaṅ. A further complication lies in the fact that the sequence takvan ikaṅ is attested also in div 28.ikaṅ ulahK

Manuscript L inserts a substantial interpolation between two iterations of the lemma. The interpolation notably contains the full text of MDhŚ 8.139 and an unidentified Sanskrit stanza. Although having stanza 8.139, with paraphrase, in this general part of the text is potentially attractive, the fact that the stanza is quoted in full is suspect, and the precise locus where it is inserted interrupts the paraphrase of 8.137. On these grounds, we favor the hypothesis that the segment of text found only in this witness is extraneous to our text.pirak paṇa sapuluhLK

In order for the arithmetic in this paragraph to work, we absolutely need this sentence to state a quantity of twelve and a half māṣas (i.e., 12 māṣa + 2 kupaṅ). Should we also supply ma before mā? Probably not, as ku in the last sentence is also not preceded by ma. For our author, ma, su seems to have been a fixed combination with ma no longer able freely to be combined with other units, as happens in the epigraphic corpus.2LK

A riṁ salek· LKA, riṁ salek· M
The witnesses clearly point to a value of 9 suvarṇas. This means the total number of māṣas in question is at least 144, i.e., a factor of 10 times the annual yield on the loan. For this reason, we conjecture that the number corruptly transmitted as A in all witnesses was a 6, reject the reading riṅ salek despite unanimous manuscript support for it, and conjecture sapuluh tahun. It is not evident why our author would have thought of a ten-year period in the present context, but it may be relevant that this duration will be mentioned explicitly two time not far below (div 130, 132).

Our author seems to have known the first Sanskrit stanza with the reading ādhisīmā. It is unclear whether he knew the second at all — whether the phrases after tan ilaṅa ya still concern the first stanza, whether they are a loose rendering of stanza 150 as we know it, or whether they correspond to a radically different version of that stanza. The use of a lowest-level instead of final punctuation after tan ilaṅa ya in all three manuscripts suggests that the scribes regarded what follows as part of the preceding paraphrase.dravyaniṅLK

aṅalaṅ-alaṅi Mśeṣaniṅ tukon … anak putuniṅ ahutaṅ L
śeṣaniṁ ḍaṇḍa, śeṣa vlan·, Ika ta kabeḥ, yan matikaṁ mahutaṁ, tan yogya tagihən hanaknya sesa vəlyan, ika ta kabeḥ yan mati kaṁ mahutaṁ, tan yogya tagihən anaknya sesaniṁ, sesa vəlyan, ika ta kabeḥ yan mati kaṁ mahutaṁ, tan yogya tagihən anaknya śeṣaniṅ daṇḍa, śeṣa vlyan, ika ta kabeh, yan matīkaṅ mahutaṅ, tan yogya tagihən hanaknya KM
The two alternative ways of reading the last sentence, represented respectively by L and K #M, seem equally acceptable. It is remarkable that where L reads śeṣaniṅ tukon, K #M seem to reflect śeṣa vlyan in their hyparchetype, while they agree with L on reading śeṣaniṅ ḍaṇḍa. There is external textual evidence in Perpusnas L882 (mvah hutaṅ tan kaliliranā deniṅ putra, hutaṅ tan paputra, hutaṅ totohan, śeṣadaṇḍa, hutaṅ tukon, hutaṅ sajə̄ṅ) that might support conjecturing śeṣa ḍaṇḍa in our text. There is also evidence that tukon and vǝlyan were felt to be equivalent in this genre of literature UBL Or 5037 (ana vvaṅ istrī linamar saptapayu sinrahan ikaṅ tukon mati taṅ istrīkaṅ sinrahan tukon vəlyan ika si baṅavan ika tan vaṅsulakna ikaṅ tukon).

kunaṅ […] sākṣinya
The readings of both witnesses cannot be reconciled with each other without doing violence to the one or the other. It is noticeable that the reading of K is much more coherent than that of L. By the principle of lectio difficilior potior, L’s’ readings should probably be preferred: they are less consistent, somewhat elliptical, and compressed, whereas K’s readings look like an expansion and systematization. For the paraphrase of the second hemistisch of the Sanskrit stanza, see .kunaṅ […] 2.
The second half of the Sanskrit stanza it not glossed at all. It is likely that corresponding sentences of the Old Javanese text have been lost due to eye-skip.ikaṅ […] yān
All witnesses read a lowest-level punctuation sign here and after the gloss of the next stanza: it seems that MDhŚ08.154–156 were considered to form a group.ikaikaṁ […] nikaṅ inakuniṅ bapanya panahuranya
This paragraph is transmitted ibn exceedingly corrupt form in all witnesses; we are forced to take recourse to extreme conjectures to obtain a coherent text.

^330 . kunaṅ […] sākṣinya] The readings of both witnesses cannot be reconciled with each other without doing violence to the one or the other. It is noticeable that the reading of K is much more coherent than that of L. By the principle of lectio difficilior potior, L’s’ readings should probably be preferred: they are less consistent, somewhat elliptical, and compressed, whereas K’s readings look like an expansion and systematization. ^406 . takvanǝn] conj., takvan LK • We cannot make sense of the text as it is transmitted, with takvan, as we require a passive verb form. There are rather numerous occurrences of takvanana in our text and in others, while takvanǝn is scarcely attested anywhere, but we favor this emendation as it seems easier to understand how the error takvan ikaṅ might have arisen from takvanǝn ikaṅ than from takvanana ikaṅ. A further complication lies in the fact that the sequence takvan ikaṅ is attested also in div 28.

nipṭiṁ vak nityaṁ* krodaṣṭaṁ*, valat śobr̥ṁ* namasṭadḍi, niṣṭe maḍyamaṁ* hutamaṁ*, purvvakaṁ* mituva ḍaṇḍaṁ*,
ka, hana ta ya: vaṁṅ apihutaṁ, tinagiḥ pihutaṁnya, tan paveḥ vetan drəvenya, hasr̥ṁ saṁṅ apihutaṁ, maṅalap sadr̥venya, maṅalap histri, sunu, bhūmi, nūn pasu sakalviriṁ patik vənaṁ yata hinalap·, vetniṁ kaṁniṣṭa vinaṅūn mityeṁṅ ūjar,, maka:don hinira:-hira:, haṅiṅindəti, haṅlindihi, tan druḥ kaṁṅ adr̥ve vaṁṅ apihutaṁ, lumka:s kaṅśa:seṁ tan hambava cihna Utər· daL̥m, hikya ṅaran valat sahaṣa havalat śobra, hiṅar:vakən vinalik rantas vitya:, mvaṁ tinibakna ḍaṇḍa mahirantaṁn kaṁ sa:hasobradḍi, kunəṁ pinaraṅgvakna vutaṁ, lavan daṇḍanekaṁ sahaṣa, vnaṅ pasaṅana vrat niṣṭa maḍyotama, ye niṣṭa vit hutaṁ mvaḥ paṅamet· sinahaṣa:, niṣṭa: ḍaṇḍa,, 5000, yen madya paṅamete, ḍaṇḍa, 10000, hutama paṅamete, ḍaṇḍa, 20000, sapaṅamete haṅsula:kna riṁ kaṁṅ avutaṅ, vaṣana, ḍaṇḍa riṁ saṁ bhūpatya || 0 || kunaṁ Ikaṁ pratekaniṁ harta:, sapaṇna:, 20, limaṁ paṇa:, 2, ku, tkeṁ hartha, kunaṁ ikaṁ pirak pana sapuluḥ, ma:, L • Manuscript L inserts a substantial interpolation between two iterations of the lemma. The interpolation notably contains the full text of MDhŚ 8.139 and an unidentified Sanskrit stanza. Although having stanza 8.139, with paraphrase, in this general part of the text is potentially attractive, the fact that the stanza is quoted in full is suspect, and the precise locus where it is inserted interrupts the paraphrase of 8.137. On these grounds, we favor the hypothesis that the segment of text found only in this witness is extraneous to our text.

^621 . mā,] , om. LKM • In order for the arithmetic in this paragraph to work, we absolutely need this sentence to state a quantity of twelve and a half māṣas (i.e., 12 māṣa + 2 kupaṅ). Should we also supply ma before mā? Probably not, as ku in the last sentence is also not preceded by ma. For our author, ma, su seems to have been a fixed combination with ma no longer able freely to be combined with other units, as happens in the epigraphic corpus.

^640 . 6, riṅ sapuluh tahun] conj., A riṁ salek· LK, A, riṁ salek· M • The witnesses clearly point to a value of 9 suvarṇas. This means the total number of māṣas in question is at least 144, i.e., a factor of 10 times the annual yield on the loan. For this reason, we conjecture that the number corruptly transmitted as A in all witnesses was a 6, reject the reading riṅ salek despite unanimous manuscript support for it, and conjecture sapuluh tahun. It is not evident why our author would have thought of a ten-year period in the present context, but it may be relevant that this duration will be mentioned explicitly two time not far below (div 130, 132).

^813 . śeṣaniṅ tukon … anak putuniṅ ahutaṅ] L, śeṣaniṁ ḍaṇḍa, śeṣa vlan·, Ika ta kabeḥ, yan matikaṁ mahutaṁ, tan yogya tagihən hanaknya , sesa vəlyan, ika ta kabeḥ yan mati kaṁ mahutaṁ, tan yogya tagihən anaknya , sesaniṁ, sesa vəlyan, ika ta kabeḥ yan mati kaṁ mahutaṁ, tan yogya tagihən anaknya , śeṣaniṅ daṇḍa, śeṣa vlyan, ika ta kabeh, yan matīkaṅ mahutaṅ, tan yogya tagihən hanaknya KM • The two alternative ways of reading the last sentence, represented respectively by L and K #M, seem equally acceptable. It is remarkable that where L reads śeṣaniṅ tukon, K #M seem to reflect śeṣa vlyan in their hyparchetype, while they agree with L on reading śeṣaniṅ ḍaṇḍa. There is external textual evidence in Perpusnas L882 (mvah hutaṅ tan kaliliranā deniṅ putra, hutaṅ tan paputra, hutaṅ totohan, śeṣadaṇḍa, hutaṅ tukon, hutaṅ sajə̄ṅ) that might support conjecturing śeṣa ḍaṇḍa in our text. There is also evidence that tukon and vǝlyan were felt to be equivalent in this genre of literature UBL Or 5037 (ana vvaṅ istrī linamar saptapayu sinrahan ikaṅ tukon mati taṅ istrīkaṅ sinrahan tukon vəlyan ika si baṅavan ika tan vaṅsulakna ikaṅ tukon).

Translation

1

When the king is going to try a case, he should enter the court modestly accompanied by Brahmins and counselors who are experts in policy Now should his Majesty undertake to attend to litigation/affairs of this world, let him take as companions Brahmins who are knowledgeable and study Scripture, and likewise ministers with the wisdom to judge with discernment; with good conduct, he should enter the council.(1)
